title: I am a cosigner on a loan and filed ch 7 and reaffirmation as well and now can no loner make payments whos' responsible???
question: this was a verbal agreement between me and a coworker. he was going to buy the car for me and make the payments the dealer listed me as the cosigner and it should have been him. The primary borrower does not respond to any notices i send him. I am ready to let the vehicle go back to the company as i can no longer make payments and have filed a chapter 7 and a reaffirmation on the vehicle
answers: Agree with other counsel regarding reaffirmation agreement, different result if you have not reaffirmed. Are you ABSOLUTELY sure that a reaffirmation was filed with the court and that it is valid? Check court records to be sure: www.ecf.gov

Most members of the public are very confused about what legal responsibility goes along with co-signed debts. Check out my legal guide on my profile page. I have attempted to explain the ramifications of signing as a co-signor on any debt. But heed all of the other Attorneys answers as well because you are on a very strict timeline to rescind the reaffirmation agreement, if that time period has not already expired.

If you filed a reaffirmation agreement and the time to rescind that reaff has passed, then you are and will continue to be responsible for the debt. You have the later of the date of your bankruptcy discharge or 60 days after the reaff was entered into the court record after the judge signed off on the reaff. If it before your discharge or 60 days from the entry of the reaff, then I'd suggest you notify the creditor that you are rescinding the reaff and also put a notice in the court record that you are doing so.

This is why you should never sign a reaffirmation on a car note without a detailed understanding of what it means, especially in the event of default. You have no bankruptcy protection, you must make the payments or lose the car and get sued for the deficiency.

You do have a very limited right to "rescind" the reaffirmation, see your attorney to understand if this is possible.

You are responsible for this debt. Your lawyer should never have signed off on a reaffirmation agreement under these circumstances. If it has been less than 60 days since you signed the reaff then you can rescind it and you wouldn't owe the money, but you need to notify the car creditor immediately, today, if you are still within that window. Otherwise you're stuck.
